column2: image=[[File:The Lord of the Rings Online - Archet map.jpg
caption=Map of Archet from ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]''
location=Central [[Eriador]], to the east of [[Bree]] in [[Bree-land]]

column1: '''Archet''' was the most remote of the settlements of the [[Bree-land]], set among the trees on the northern edge of the [[Chetwood]], somewhat to the east of [[Bree]] itself.<ref>{{FR
column2: I9}}</ref> A few [[hobbits]] lived there, but the inhabitants were predominantly [[Big Folk]].

column1: When the hobbits and [[Gandalf]] returned to Bree after their journey south, [[Barliman Butterbur]] told them of the fight within Bree in which some Bree-landers were killed.  After the fight the robbers took to hiding in the woods beyond Archet.<ref>{{RK
The name ''Archet'' is said to be an "English place-name of [[Celtic]] origin", sharing the element ''chet'' "wood" with ''[[Chetwood#Etymology
column3: N}}, p. 765</ref> [[Mark T. Hooker]] has suggested that the element ''[[Wiktionary:ar-#Old_Irish
column4: Ar-]]'' is a prefix meaning "nearby", found in several [[Welsh]] place-names. The meaning of ''Archet'' would thus be "near the woods", which Hooker notes describes its geographic position "''on the edge of the Chetwood''".<ref>[[Mark T. Hooker]], ''[[A Tolkienian Mathomium]]'', p. 8</ref>

column1: Its form suggests a natural evolution of a Celtic word borrowed in the [[Old English]] times as ''Arcet'', to the modern English.<ref name=etym/>
''Archet'' is equivalent to the real-life [[Welsh]] name ''[[Wikipedia:Argoed
column2: Argoed]]'', with the same meaning "By the woods".<ref name=etym>{{webcite

column1: :Archet is the settlement players start at if they are Hobbits or of the Race of Man. During the [[Bree-land Introduction
column2: introduction]] of the ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online: Shadows of Angmar
column3: Shadows of Angmar]]'' it comes under attack by [[Blackwolds
column4: Blackwold]] brigands who burn many of the homes to the ground. The settlement is commanded by Captain Brackenbrook, a retired sell-sword, but command passes on to his son, [[Jon Brackenbrook]], when his father is killed in the attack.
